message.content:
cs.IT, cs.DS, cs.CC, cs.SI, cs.LG. 

The paper deals with information theory and its applications to distributed source and channel coding problems, which are typically categorized under cs.IT (Information Theory). The concepts of additive and tensorizing functions are also relevant to distributed computing and communication, which fall under cs.DS (Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing). The paper also discusses rate regions and capacity regions, which are important in network coding and communication, and hence, cs.CC (Networking and Internet Architecture) is another likely sub-category. The measures of correlation and their applications to distributed source and channel coding problems suggest that the paper could also be categorized under cs.SI (Social and Information Networks). Finally, the paper uses mathematical tools and techniques to derive its results, which could make it relevant to cs.LG (Machine Learning).
